titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Kathy Dobkin Papers TAM.852
titlestmt.author: Shannon O'Neill, Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-06-12 20:14:00 UTC.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 9 manuscript boxes, 1 media box, and 22 audiocassettes in shared housing

did.abstract: Kathy Dobkin was a broadcaster at WNET (Channel 13) and WBAI from the 1970s to the early 2000s. In September 1970, Dobkin led a station-wide effort to produce an on-air reading of Leo Tolstoy's War and Peace, unabridged and with a Soviet musical score. The production, which lasted five straight days for 24 hours a day, was at that point was the longest continuous on-air broadcast in radio history. The Kathy Dobkin Papers (dated 1952-2018) consists of materials created and collected by Dobkin documenting her work at WBAI, with particular emphasis on the station's on-air broadcast of War and Peace. Materials include ephemera, production files, research materials, and press clippings, as well as audio recordings of the broadcast. The collection also includes a smaller amount of personal correspondence and materials on the history of WBAI. In addition to documenting this particular project, the materials in this collection also reflect Soviet arts and culture, particularly through the lens of the Cold War, through Dobkin's research materials.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English, with a significant amount of correspondence, ephemera, and publications in Russian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Kathy Dobkin Papers (dated 1952-2018) consists of materials created and collected by Dobkin documenting her work at WBAI, with particular emphasis on the station's on-air broadcast of War and Peace. Materials include ephemera, production files, research materials, and press clippings, as well as audio recordings of the broadcast. The collection also includes a smaller amount of personal correspondence and materials on the history of WBAI. In addition to documenting this particular project, the materials in this collection also reflect Soviet arts and culture, particularly through the lens of the Cold War, through Dobkin's research materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: During acquisition, the following items were appraised out of the collection by the curator: duplicate promotional materials for the War and Peace marathon reading (including duplicative posters and postcards); Dobkin's childhood report cards and diplomas; off-air recordings of Democracy Now! episodes; and optical discs duplicating the physical collection or held by the Pacifica Radio Archives.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by the Katherin Dobkin Living Trust in May 2025; the accession number associated with this gift is 2025.055.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Born-Digital Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Kathy Dobkin Papers; TAM 852; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused in archival boxes and folders, maintaining the creator's original order and in many cases, folder titles. Materials were described on the collection-level, with a folder-level inventory. Audiovisual items were inventoried at the item-level. Born-digital items on physical carriers were identified, physically separated, and inventoried. Optical discs that duplicated the collection's physical holdings, were protected by copyright restrictions, and/or are held at other archival repositories were deaccessioned. Three optical discs were forensically imaged, analyzed, and described. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Kathy Dobkin was a broadcaster at WNET (Channel 13) and WBAI from the 1970s to the early 2000s. In September 1970, Dobkin led a station-wide effort to produce an on-air reading of Leo Tolstoy's War and Peace, unabridged and with a Soviet musical score. The production, which lasted five straight days for 24 hours a day, was at that point was the longest continuous on-air broadcast in radio history.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: WBAI recordings of the War and Peace broadcast, as well as commemorations of the event, were held by the Pacifica Radio Archives until 2024, after which they have been transferred to the American Archive of Public Broadcasting.
